author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: abhoth
overview: A grayish, horrid mass that nearly choked it from rim to rim... Here, it seemed, was the ultimate source of all miscreation and abomination. For the gray mass quobbed and quivered, and swelled perpetually; and from it, in manifold fission, were spawned the anatomies that crept away on every side through the grotto. There were things like bodiless legs or arms that flailed in the slime, or heads that rolled, or floundering bellies with fishes' fins; and all manner of things malformed and monstrous, that grew in size as they departed from the neighborhood of Abhoth. And those that swam not swiftly ashore when they fell into the pool from Abhoth, were devoured by mouths that gaped in the parent bulk.

author: Crispin Burnham
name: apocolothoth
overview: undefined

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: atlach-natcha
overview: The dark form ran toward him with incredible swiftness. When it came near he saw that there was a kind of face on the squat ebon body, low down amid the several-jointed legs. The face peered up with a weird expression of doubt and inquiry; and terror crawled through the veins of the bold huntsman as he met the small, crafty eyes that were circled about with hair.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: azahoth
nicks: supreme lord and creator of all things
overview: There can be no definite description of Azathoth, because everybody envisions him differently and he is always changing. But H.P.L. defines it: 'Outside the ordered universe [is] that amorphous blight of nethermost confusion which blasphemes and bubbles at the center of all infinityâ€”the boundless daemon sultan Azathoth, whose name no lips dare speak aloud, and who gnaws hungrily in inconceivable, unlighted chambers beyond time and space amidst the muffled, maddening beating of vile drums and the thin monotonous whine of accursed flutes.'

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: basatan
overview: By the look of the ring 'with the tentacles of a kraken clasping the orb-like gem' and the visions that one of the characters sees in the orb 'swirling as of tides and of shadowy fins and tentacles far down in its glimmering greenness' we can assume that he has tentacles and/or fins.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: bokrug
overview: Bokrug is the lake-dwelling god of the semi-amphibian Thuum'ha ('Voiceless Ones') of Ib in the land of Mnar. The deity sleeps beneath the calm waters of a lake that bordered Ib and the city of Sarnath. When the humans of Sarnath cruelly slaughtered the populace of Ib and stole the god's idol, the great deity stirred. Each year thereafter, strange ripples reportedly disturbed the otherwise placid lake. On the one-thousandth anniversary of Ib's destruction, Bokrug rose up and utterly destroyed the city of Sarnath, so completely that not even ruins remained. Afterwards, the Thuum'ha race recolonised Ib and thenceforth lived undisturbed.

author: Robert Bloch
name: byatis
overview: Appears as a gigantic, multicolored toad with a single eye, claws similar to a crabs and a beard of tentacles. An 18th-century document relates that a statue of the creature. Later the document says the monster is 'somewhat like a Spider, somewhat like a Crab, and somewhat like a Horror in Dreams.' It reports that the 'Romans found it behind a stone Door in a Camp which was here long before the Invasion.'

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: byakhee
nicks: servants of he not to be named
overview: A horde of tame, trained hybrid winged things that no sound eye could ever wholly grasp, or sound brain ever wholly remember. There flapped rhythmically a horde of tame, trained, hybrid winged things... not altogether crows, nor moles, nor buzzards, nor ants, nor decomposed human beings, but something I cannot and must not recall.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: cat from saturn
overview: undefined

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: cat of sadoqua
overview: undefined

author: Frank Belknap Long
name: chaugnar faugn
overview: Words could not adequately convey the repulsiveness of the thing. It was endowed with a trunk and great, uneven ears, and two enormous tusks protruded from the corners of its mouth. But it was not an elephant. Indeed, its resemblace to an actual elephant was, at best, sporadic and superficial, despite certain unmistakable points of similarity. The ears were webbed and tentacled, the trunk terminated in a huge flaring disk at least a foot in diameter, and the tusks, which intertwined and interlocked at the base of the statue, were as translucent as rock crystal.

author: Brian Lumley
name: chthonians
overview: Immense worms, with tough elongated bodies coated with vicious slime

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: colour out of space
overview: Globules of colour that are referred to as such 'only by analogy', as they do not fall within the range of anything known in the visible spectrum.

author: August Derleth
name: cthugha
overview: Cthugha resembles a giant ball of fire. He is served by the Flame Creatures of Cthugha. Fthaggua, regent of the fire vampires, may be his progeny. He has at least one other known progeny, the being known as Aphoom-Zhah.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: cthulhu
nicks: high priest of the great old ones
overview: The most detailed descriptions of Cthulhu are based on statues of the creature. One, constructed by an artist after a series of baleful dreams, is said to have 'yielded simultaneous pictures of an octopus, a dragon, and a human caricature [...] A pulpy, tentacled head surmounted a grotesque and scaly body with rudimentary wings.' Another, recovered by police from a raid on a murderous cult, 'represented a monster of vaguely anthropoid outline, but with an octopus-like head whose face was a mass of feelers, a scaly, rubbery-looking body, prodigious claws on hind and fore feet, and long, narrow wings behind.'

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: cxaxukluth
overview: It is described as an androgynous being, capable of reproducing asexually.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: dagon
overview: Dagon is an enormous specimen of a Deep One that has been mentioned in texts since at least the time of Mesopotamia. A half man, half fish, like a merman.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: darkness
overview: undefined

author: Robert Bloch
name: dark young of shub-niggurath
overview: They stand as tall as a tree on stumpy, hoofed legs. A mass of tentacles protrudes from their trunks where a head would normally be, and puckered maws, dripping green goo, cover their flanks. The monsters roughly resemble trees in silhouette â€” the trunks being the short legs and the tops of the trees represented by the ropy, branching bodies. The whole mass of these things smells like an open grave.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: deep one
overview: The Deep Ones are an amphibious race that primarily serve the two beings known as Father Dagon and Mother Hydra, but also have strong ties to Cthulhu, and are known to employ Shoggoths as servants.

author: Pierre Zaplotny
name: d'endrrah
overview: D'endrrah is a being who possesses a great hunger for living worlds. It often manifests in the form of a gigantic squid-like monster or a cloud of heavy, smoky, organic matter with millions of teeth, which wanders the cosmos endlessly to devour any world it stumbles across.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: dhole
overview: Gigantic worms reaching over 600 ft. in length and 20 ft. thick; their skin is armor-clad with thick chitinous-like sections. At one end is the feasting mouth, hidden beneath a segmented aperture, which closes right when burrowing below

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: dimensional shambler
overview: Hulking extra-dimensional entities, seemingly outlandish combinations of crustacean, insect, and ape-like mammal. In places, their hide is like thick plates of armor, while the rest of the skin is loose and rugose. The eyes appear as black points of light set in a rudimentary head. The mouth is a misshapen hole. Large talon-like clawed appendages protrude from the arms.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: elder thing
overview: Gray colored, barrel-shaped entities; the central mass displays five vertical ridges, between which wing-like membranes can unfold from interior cavities. Spaced around the central body mass are present five flexible arms, each ending in a conglomeration of small tentacles or tendrils. From the bulbous neck a five-pointed starfish-like 'head' rises. The head have five stalks ending in eyes. Atop the head is present an aperture not unlike a mouth. Below the central body are five flexible legs, each ending in a paddle or flipper-like appendage.

author: August Derleth
name: e-poh
overview: E-poh is a Tcho-Tcho sorcerer from the fabled city of Alaozar in the Plateau of Sung, Burma, and leads his people in worship of Zhar and Lloigor. He is 'slightly taller' than the typical four-foot-tall Tcho-Tcho, and 'disfigured by a hump on his back'. He is said to be over 7,000 years old.

author: Donald Wandrei
name: fire vampire
overview: The Fire Vampires are living extensions of the cosmic entity known as Fthaggua. Traveling the cosmos in their interstellar ship, the Ktynga, they appear as bluish electrical discharges resembling lightning. They feast upon the life energy of sentient creatures. The victim will burst into flames during this process, with the Fire Vampires consuming their essence and memories using heat instead of internal metabolization. These stolen memories are added to Fthaggua's gestalt consciousness, allowing them to learn better and adapt to consuming more.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: flying polyp
overview: Unlike animals or plants, these entities twist and form a dark plastic flesh, cancerous with strange growths amidst multiple eyes and mouths. Semi-material, elements or portions seems to phase between visible and invisible. No wings can be seen, despite a floating or hovering appearance, although they must walk, jump, or crawl on invisible limbs, as where they went, certain strange marks are left off a footprint consisting of five circular toe marks, some 6 ft. in total lenght.

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: formless spawn of tsathoggua
overview: A living ooze able to take temporary forms, like a mass of undulating limbs, or a great sphere possessing many mouths.

author: Donald Wandrei
name: fthaggua
nicks: the king regent of the fire vampires
overview: A great flickering ball of cold blue flame. It dwells with the Fire Vampires within an enormous edifice upon the surface of the blue comet Ktynga, a celestial body which Fthaggua can guide across the cosmos and which is possessed of many strange properties, not least the incredible heat that it radiates or the fact that it can exceed the speed of light.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: ghast
overview: Ghasts may be encountered in places where sunlight never comes, such as underworld labyrinths, cavern networks, and deep tunnel systems. They shun light and are fearful of the sun, as when they are exposed to direct sunlight they sicken and may eventually die. Like the ghouls, the ghasts have sharp hooves for feet, although they are larger and move around by hopping. Their faces are eerily humanoid, but have neither a nose nor a forehead.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: ghatanothoa
overview: Might call it giganticâ€”tentacledâ€”proboscidianâ€”octopus-eyedâ€”semi-amorphousâ€”plasticâ€”partly squamous and partly rugose.

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: ghizguth
nicks: the sound in the deep waters
overview: undefined

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: ghoul
overview: Ghouls in Lovecraft's fiction are mortal beings: a species of canine-like humanoids with rubbery skin, scaly claws, and hoof-like feet, which live in groups and scavenge for corpses, but also hunt live prey occasionally.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: gloon
overview: Gloon is described as great limacene or slug-like abomination, though it usually hides its true nature through the glamour of a beautiful statue resembling the Greek god Dionysus.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: gnoph-keh
overview: A polar bear monstrosity, with six-limbs and covered in shaggy white hair. From its forehead rise a single horn, while its great mouth was filled with wicked and sharp teeth. It may walk upright on two legs or bear-like on four, but other times it uses all its six limbs.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: great race of yith
overview: Beings resembling large cones with a muscular foot for locomotion and four extensible arms or tentacles projecting from the apex. Two of these arms ended in claws or pincers, the third terminated in four clustered trumpet-like organs, and the fourth was topped with a spherical yellow 'head' with three dark eyes, four stalked flower-like hearing organs on top, and a number of green tentacles dangling beneath. Their blood was dark green and very thick.

author: Lin Carter
name: gray weaver
overview: undefined

author: Sandy Peterson
name: gobogeg
overview: A colossal pillar of amorphous alien flesh, with a cyclopean head or eye in the center.

author: Donald Wandrei
name: god of the red flux
overview: A vaporous red entity haunting the rainforest of Central Africa. It has the power to turn humans into zombie-like minions, the Tree-Men of M'bwa.

author: Robert E. Howard
name: gol-goroth
overview: Gol-goroth appears as a titanic, black toad-like monstrosity with an impossibly malevolent glare, or a tentacle covered, scaly, bat-winged entity. However, its physical form may alter to fit the worst nightmares of whoever is viewing it.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: gug
overview: Gugs are large, black-furred beasts with vertically-opening fanged jaws. Their two eyes protrude from either side of their head, and their limbs bifurcate at the elbows, giving them four separate forearms. They are worshippers of the Great Ones, the gods of Earth who reside in Kadath. Gugs are estimated to reach around sixteen feet in heights and weigh in at nearly 2,000 pounds.

author: Robert Bloch
name: han
overview: undefined

author: Ambrose Bierce
name: hastur
nicks: him who is not to be named
great pPrince of the old ines
overview: Hastur is amorphous, but he is said to appear as a vast, vaguely octopoid being.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: high priest not to be described
overview: The Priest appears as a man covered by a yellow robe and with his face hidden behind a silk mask. Although they are not clearly described, it seems that he has terrifying hands.

author: Frank Belknap Long
name: hound of tindalos
overview: The Hounds of Tindalos are said to inhabit the 'angles' of time; in contrast, humans and other earthly lifeforms live within the 'curves' of time. Little is known about their appearance, as few victims survive their attacks; however, they are known to have hollow proboscises used for feeding, and are associated with a blue pus-like substance.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: hunting horror
overview: undefined

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: hypnos
overview: He appears as a youthful man with a bearded face, 'immense, sunken and widely luminous eyes', and a crown of poppies.

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: hziulquoigmnzhah
overview: Ludicrously short legs â€¦ exceedingly elongated arms, and a round, sleepy-looking head that was pendulous from a spherical body

author: Henry Kuttner
name: iod
overview: Iod is a conglomeration of plant, mineral, and animal which appears first as a veil or great black shadow in the air, followed by a blinding night after which it emerges. Its body consists of pulsing luminous crystals and mineral formations inside an envelop of squamous, translucent flesh, with a large faceted eye and vine-like tentacles. After paralyzing its victims, Iod drains away their life force with its tendrils until only the victim's brain remains conscious. This consciousness lives on within the corpse, trapped for all eternity.

author: August Derleth
name: ithaqua
overview: Ithaqua is one of the Great Old Ones and appears as a horrifying giant with a roughly human shape and glowing red eyes. He has been reported from as far north as the Arctic to the Sub-Arctic, where Native Americans first encountered him. He is believed to prowl the Arctic waste, hunting down unwary travelers and slaying them in a gruesome fashion. He is believed to have inspired the Native American legend of the Wendigo and possibly the Yeti.

author: Circle Colaboration
name: juk-shabb
overview: Juk-Shabb is a Great Old One which communicates by changing color and using telepathy. The being is a powerful psionic and has extensive knowledge of magic. Among the Great Old Ones, it is one of the least malevolent. Appears as a huge shining ball of sentient energy.

author: R. H. Barlow
name: krang
overview: A monstrous brown, leathery, alien entity native to a mysterious planet, Krang currently slumbers within a gigantic mausoleum lost in the desert-wastes. It is set to guard a priceless treasure made up of the oldest decayed planets.

author: Lin Carter
name: k'thuggoul
overview: Like a typical shoggoth, K'thugguol is described as a large, gelatinous, amoeboid creature with myriads of eyestalks. It dwells deep in the subterranean realm of grey-litten Y'qaa and guards the entrance of the pit inhabited by Ubbo-Sathla.

author: August Derleth
name: lloigor
overview: Their enormous tentacles are entangled with each other's bodies, which lie in distant parts of the same cave. The two constantly emit strange humming sounds at each other as they have for millennia since being imprisoned there by the Elder Gods.

author: Colin Wilson
name: lloigors
nicks: the invisible ones from the stars
overview: The Lloigor are vortices of living power completely invisible except on occasions when they appear reptilian.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: magnum innominandum
overview: Its powers include possible omnipresence, reality warping, acausality, spacetime manipulation, immortality, and incorporeality.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: mi-go
overview: Several types of Mi-go exist, including winged and wingless variations. Those that have wings use them to fly through the 'ether' of outer space. They are described as being most like fungi, although their outward appearance is much like that of a crustacean, and they also have something akin to chlorophyll. Their blood has been described as a 'foetid green ichor' or a 'green sticky stuff'. Interestingly, they are capable of going into suspended animation until softened and reheated by the sun or some other source of heat.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: moon-beast
overview: They are pale, squat, toadlike creatures, superhumanly strong and noxious-smelling, having no eyes but instead a mass of pink tentacles at the end of their snout.

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: mordiggian
overview: Described as swirling darkness, a gigantic shadow, or a worm-shaped column, Mordiggian is worshipped by several human cults and cults of ghouls as a symbol of Death.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: mormo
overview: Mormo is a shapeshifting female entity known for having three forms: The first form, is a mocking vampire-like maiden who may or may not be wearing Victorian Era style clothing; Second, a gorgon-like creature with tentacles for hair instead of snakes; And lastly, a large toad-like creature with tentacles for a face, akin to her servitors the Moon-beasts.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: mother hydra
overview: An enormous specimen of a Deep One that has been mentioned in texts since at least the time of Mesopotamia. A half man, half fish, like a merman.

author: Lin Carter
name: naggoob
overview: undefined

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: n'gha-kthun
overview: undefined

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: night-gaunt
overview: Night-gaunts are a species of flying creatures inhabiting Earth's Dreamlands. They are described as having smooth whale-like skin, long slender humanoid bodies, curving horns, leather bat-like wings, and a blank expanse of flesh where one would expect a face to be.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: nodens
overview: Nodens is also described with '...the grey and awful form of primal Nodens, Lord of the Great Abyss.'

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: nug
overview: undefined

author: Robert A. W. Lowndes
name: nyaghoggua
overview: undefined

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: nyarlathotep
nicks: father of the million favored ones
the god of a thousand forms
the god of the bloody tongue
overview: Nyarlathotep is active and frequently walks the Earth in the guise of a human being, usually a tall, slim, joyous man. He has 'a thousand' other forms and manifestations, many reputed to be quite horrific and sanity-blasting.

author: Henry Kuttner
name: nyogtha
nicks: the haunter of the red abyss
the thing which should not be
overview: Nyogtha is an amorphous mass composed of an unidentifiable sticky black substance. It is capable of extruding tentacles from this mass to manipulate the environment around it.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: oorn
overview: A pudgy creature with short grey-colored fur and three small red eyes, Oorn is believed to have originated from the mysterious 'outer abyss', and was found on the outskirts of the city of Zeth, located on an extraterrestrial planet, long before the dawn of humanity on Earth.

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: quachil uttaus
overview: A figure no larger than a young child, but sere and shriveled as some millennial mummy. Its hairless head, its unfeatured face, borne on a neck of skeleton thinness, were lined with a thousand reticulated wrinkles. His body like that of some monstrous, withered abortion that had never drawn breath. The pipy arms, ending in bony claws, were outthrust as if ankylosed in a posture of an eternal dreadful groping.

author: Lin Carter
name: quumyagga
overview: Quumyagga is a giant bird-like creature covered in both feathers and scales, with a single eye and a single leg, as well as a hooked beak.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: rat-thing
overview: The Rat People are rat-human hybrids who can be both bipedal and quadrupedal. They were all once human, but have degenerated due to inbreeding and the worship of gods such as Y'golonac.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: rhan-tegoth
overview: Rhan-Tegoth is a fifteen foot tall, medusa-like, insectoid amphibious god-being (Great Old One) of comparatively little power but vital to the return of the Old Ones. It lived in the warm seas of Yuggoth before coming to Earth.

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: rlim shaikorth
overview: Appearing as a gigantic, pale, white worm with a great gaping maw and empty sockets for eyes that drip blood continuously.

author: August Derleth
name: sand-dweller
overview: They resemble 'emaciated, grit-encrusted humans with koala-like heads.

author: Robert Bloch
name: sebek
overview: A slanted, saurian skull, all green and scaly on top; hairless, slimy, slick and nauseous. Great bony ridges socketed the embered eyes, staring from behind a sickening sweep of long, reptilian snout. A rugose muzzle, with great champing jaws half opened to reveal a lolling pinkish tongue and scummy teeth of stilleto-like sharpness.

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: serpent person
overview: Serpent People are a nonhuman species which, although possessing somewhat humanoid limbs, strongly resembles snakes.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: servitor of the outer gods
overview: The Servitors of the Outer Gods are amorphous beings that resemble squids, frogs, and octopi which are constantly changing their shape and appearance. When needed they accompany the Outer Gods, though most of them are in the Court of Azathoth.

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: sfatlicllp
nicks: great old one who mated with voormis
overview: undefined

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: shantak
overview: Lovecraft depicts them as a flying bird-like creature larger than elephants, with heads resembling those of horses. They have scales rather than feathers, and lay eggs of colossal size and rich flavor. They are allied with Nyarlathotep, and fear the Night-gaunt minions of Nodens.

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: shathak
overview: undefined

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: shaurash-ho
overview: undefined

author: R. H. Barlow
name: shista
overview: A shape-shifting Great Old One that mainly manifests as a spiny five-legged crab, Shista possesses a spider-like head and wears metallic bracelets on each limb.

author: August Derleth
name: sho-gath
overview: It is depicted as a dark smoky column, with red malevolent eyes and a grotesque face, imprisoned inside a vintage box.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: shoggoth
overview: A shoggoth is a sentient blob of self-shaping, gelatinous flesh, something like a giant amoeba. A shoggoth is some 15 feet in diameter if it shaped itself into a sphere, but larger and smaller versions exist. A shoggoth is capable of shaping itself into whatever organs or shapes it finds necessary at the moment; however, in its usual state it tends to sport a roiling profusion of eyes, mouths, and pseudopodia. When encountered at the South Pole, it moved at incredible speed. It was described as like watching a train closing in on someone standing on the tracks.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: shub-niggurath
nicks: the black goat with a thousand young
overview: An enormous mass which extrudes black tentacles, slime-dripping mouths, and short, writhing goat legs. Small creatures are continually spat forth by the monstrosity, which are either consumed into the miasmatic form or escape to some monstrous life elsewhere.

author: Brian Lumley
name: shudde m'ell
overview: Shudde M'ell appears as a colossal worm with tentacles sprouting from its head, and is so large that it can cause earthquakes by simply moving. Shudde M'ell is a mile long great grey worm-like creature that burrows through the earth, melting all rocks in its wake. It is believed to be the supreme regent of the Chthonians as well as the largest and most powerful of the race.

author: Henry Kuttner
name: star spawn of cthulhu
overview: A mountainous form lumbers to life, a hideous creature only accidentally humanoid in shape, its hateful face a writhing mass of tentacles.

author: Robert Bloch
name: star vampire
overview: Star Vampires are creatures from outer space that are normally invisible. They are voracious blood suckers, becoming visible once their bodies are full of the victim's blood, a vivid red colour. Its form is like that of a jellyfish with neither a head or any visible facial features apart from its huge maw. Their bodies have multiple muscular tentacles, each strong enough to crush a man to death and on the tips are the suckers with which it drains the blood of its victims. From the star vampires comes nonstop eerie horrifying laughter.

author: Robert A. W. Lowndes
name: sthanee
overview: Manifesting as a gigantic marine horror with twelve serpentine limbs equipped with suckers similar to those found on an octopus, Sthanee also has a beard of tentacles.

author: Lin Carter
name: ta-vho-shai
overview: undefined

author: Lin Carter
name: tch'tkaa
overview: undefined

author: August Derleth
name: tcho-tcho
overview: They are genetically from humans, but they are notably smaller, have livid red skin, and other marked physiological differences. Legends point to prehistoric genetic engineering of pre-human ancestors by the Great Old Ones Zhar and Lloigor. These legends purport they 'grew from the 'seeds' of the Twin Obscenities.

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: thasaidon
overview: undefined

author: Robert E. Howard
name: thog
overview: An octopus-like monstrosity of the Hyborian Age, Thog is a man eating abomination which haunts the underground city of Xuthal.

author: Donald Wandrei
name: Tree-man of M'bwa
overview: The Tree-Men were the unfortunate victims of an evil undead being named M'bwa, an entity in service to the alien God of the Red Flux.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: tru'nembra
overview: Tru'nembra, The Flautist of Azathoth, is an Outer God who resides eternally in the Court of Azathoth. Tru'nembra does not possess an instrument for he himself is an instrument. He is made entirely out of visible noise and is seemingly unintelligent, just like his master. When Tru'nembra is summoned, it brings along the maddening symphony it uses to keep its master asleep, bringing insanity to those who are unfortunate enough to hear its blaring chaos.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: tsathoggua
overview: A sleepy black toad. He will rise not from his place, even in the ravening of hunger, but will wait in divine slothfulness for the sacrifice.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: tulzscha
overview: Tulzscha appears as a blazing green ball of flame, dancing with its Lesser Outer Gods at the court of Azathoth. When summoned to the world of men, it manifests in a gaseous form, penetrating the planet to the core, then erupting from below as a pillar of flame. It is unable to move from the point it emerges.

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: ubbo-sathla
overview: It is described as a huge protoplasmic mass resting in a grotto deep beneath the frozen earth. The being is of a monstrous fecundity, spontaneously generating primordial single-celled organisms that pour unceasingly from its shapeless form. It guards a set of stone tablets believed to contain the knowledge of the Elder Gods.

author: Lin Carter
name: ubb
overview: A large, aquatic entity similar to a chthonian, Ubb is pale gray and slug-like with a large mouth full of horn-like teeth, ringed with tentacles.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: 'umr at-tawill
overview: He appears as a heavily cloaked, vaguely humanoid figure, with no organs or features discernible beneath his garb.

author: Lin Carter
name: voorm
overview: undefined

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: voormi
overview: The Voormis are described as three-toed, umber-colored, fur-covered humanoids[1] though they are carefully differentiated from their traditional enemies (the shaggier-haired but superficially similar Gnophkehs who worshiped the Great Old One Rhan-Tegoth). Both of them are further differentiated from true humans. The Voormis communicate by dog-like howls.

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: vulthoom
overview: a gigantic plant, with innumerable roots, pale and swollen, that ramified from a bulbular hole. His bole, half hidden from view, is topped with a vermilion cup like a monstrous blossom; and from the cup there grow an elfin figure, pearly-hued, and formed with exquisite beauty and symmetry.

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: xexanoth
overview: undefined

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: yaddithian
overview: A clawed, snouted beings with his body partly squamous, and curiously articulated in a fashion mainly insect-like.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: yeb
overview: undefined

author: Brian Lumley
name: yegg-ha
overview: A faceless bat-winged giant that was 'killed' by Roman soldiers near Hadrian's Wall in Britain, c.128 A.D.

author: Ramsey Campbell
name: y'golonac
overview: Y'golonac is imprisoned behind a wall of bricks in unknown ruins. His true form is uncertain, but when he possesses a human host to manifest, he appears as a grotesquely obese man, lacking a head or neck, with a mouth in the palm of each hand. Unlike other deities, Y'golonac is clearly capable of understanding humans, to the point of being able to conduct a conversation in English through his human host.

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: yhoundeh
overview: Although given the epithet of 'the Elk-Goddess', Youndeh's true appearance is never given. However, in a letter to Robert H. Barlow dated 10 September 1934 Smith stated it to be the offspring of the 'androgynous animal archetype' ZyhumÃ©. The same letter also stated that the marriage of Yhoundeh and Nyarlathotep is mentioned in Parchments of Pnom.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: yig
overview: An odd, half-anthropomorphic devil of highly arbitrary and capricious nature. He was not wholly evil, and was usually quite well-disposed toward those who gave proper respect to him and his children, the serpents; but in the autumn he became abnormally ravenous, and had to be driven away by means of suitable rites.

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: yog-sothoth
overview: Yog-Sothoth visually manifests as a mass of glowing orbs, with eyes or tendrils in some versions, and in others simply the orbs. It is heavily implied that Yog-Sothoth is omniscient, and is locked outside the universe, meaning he can know and see all of space-time all at once, which means there is no secret hidden from Yog-Sothoth.

author: August Derleth
name: zhar
overview: undefined

author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft
name: zoogs
overview: The zoogs are a race of sentient forest-dwelling creatures that inhabit the Dreamlands of Earth. They are mortal enemies of cats, as they prey upon kittens and are preyed upon in return by adult cats.

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: Zstylzhemghi
overview: Whilst information on Zstylzhemghi is scarce, her epithet leads many to believe that she is some kind of monstrous insectoid creature. However, due to the nature of the Great Old Ones, her true appearance could be virtually anything.

author: Henry Kuttner
name: zushakon
overview: A swirling, black vortex, revered by the Mutsune Native Americans as a dire death god

author: Clark Ashton Smith
name: zvilpogghua
nicks: the minion of the great old one
overview: Usually takes the form of an armless, winged, bipedal toad with a long, rubbery neck and a face completely covered in tentacles.
